readability_reflection: I found string interpolation more readable. Concatenation, with using +, was more confusing to read because I kept getting confused with arithmetic. Some of the examples in this survey included concatenations like (1+1+1+1) and it took me a few seconds to not read this as arithmetic but as string concatenation. With string interpolation, the strings themselves are defined as variables that are simply (visually simple to understand) inserted into strings like {string}, and it just makes it easier to read because the "{ }" can't be confused with other common symbols, like + for addition. Also, the "{ }" look like dividers which more clearly show where the string is being inserted. Concatenation doesn't have clearly visible barriers, unlike "{ }", so I also got confused with seeing where strings ended and started.
comprehension_debugging: Yes. Understanding the code with interpolation was much simpler than concatenation. With concatenation, it took time for me to see where strings ended, where strings began, where with interpolation I can more clearly see this division as well as visually understand how & where strings are being inserted.
preference_rationale:
I've had to do assignments and projects in the past where regular concatenation, with +, was simpler, but overall I tend to prefer interpolation. I have a lot of experience with using string interpolation in my projects that influenced my decision. To be specific, I do a lot of work with web development with Vue.js, and I use {{example}} a lot for string interpolation into my "html". An example is

Cost: {{cost}}

. Alongside these projects, and other projects, I've used a lot of TypeScript and JavaScript, and for printing statements (like cout and printf) with string interpolation, you would write console.log(`hello ${examplemsg}`);. I use string interpolation like this frequently for printing errors, like console.log(`Error: ${err}`);. So in Vue.js/TS/JS you can use {{ }} or ${ }. I don't really find myself using string concatenation as often as I do with string interpolation. The most useful example that I remember for needing string concatenation was for a recursive function of a tree, and basically the function needed to return a string, representing the path to a node (a leaf node), formed by concatenating "0"'s and "1"'s, depending on left/right path, as the function went up the tree from a leaf node and back to the main caller. Besides that though I would generally chose string interpolation.
learning_curve:
I use a lot of JavaScript (JS) and TypeScript (TS) with the Vue.js frontend framework for web development. To print statements in JS and TS with variables, you write console.log(`Hello ${name}`);. In Vue.js's "html", I use a lot of string interpolation for displaying dynamic data, like

Cost: {{cost}}

. "${ }" and "{{ }}" are the main ways that I regularly use string interpolation, and I use string interpolation much more regularly than string concatenation (although I remember having to use something like

{{firstName+ lastName}}

, and in this case concatenation is useful when I have user's names split between first and last name). Overall, my regular use of string interpolation made it much more easier for me to understand the examples. I regularly use string interpolation in similar ways that the examples provide.
suggestions_improvement: I think string concatenation is useful in some cases, with the two examples I provided being such cases. Overall though, unless the strings being concatenated aren't variables themselves, then in general it is easier to read code that uses string interpolation rather than string concatenation. Things like "1"+"1"+"1"+"1" can be confusing to read, but I feel like concatenation in examples like cout << firstName+ lastName << endl;, compared to string interpolation like cout << {firstName}{lastName } << endl;, are both fairly understandable to read (although I prefer the latter, and you could make it so adding a space w/ quotes like cout << "{myName} {lastName }" << endl; would generate a space in the console too). I'm not really sure of any other suggestions right now, but in general string interpolation makes code more easier to read than string concatenation in my opinion.
